headline: Tammi's Crawfish Etoufee
description: Mushrooms and crawfish, simmered in half and half with Parmesan cheese and parsley. Seasoned with crushed red pepper and Creole seasoning. Serve over fettuccini noodles.
name: Tammi's Crawfish Etoufee

recipeInstructions.text: In a large skillet over medium heat, heat butter and olive oil together. Saute garlic powder and mushrooms until mushrooms are tender; about 3 to 5 minutes.
Add crawfish and onions. Reduce heat to low and cook for 5 minutes.
Stir in Parmesan cheese, parsley, and half and half. Simmer for 5 minutes and stir in crushed red pepper and Creole seasoning. Salt and pepper to taste.

review.reviewBody: This was delicious! Didnâ€™t have mushrooms but used fresh garlic, added yellow onions and threw in spinach. Used a pound of frozen pre cooked crawfish so I needed to thicken sauce a little with corn starch. Will definitely make this again!

I can't get fresh crawfish where I live and frozen are $5.00 each so I went with large shrimp and scallops. I cut the portions back to three and served it over linguini. I looked everywhere but there was no creole seasoning so I used cajun. I rarely made the same recipe twice but this will be a repeat! Thanks for sharing
#AllrecipesAllstarsCanada
#Facelessnomore
We loved this recipe at our house! I will use this recipe over and over again. This recipe is perfect for a special occasion.

I have no idea why this recipe has not been rated more often but it's one of the best that i have come across and I'm from Louisiana! I have also prepared this using shrimp and scallops and it works really well with both. The BEST!

i thought it was pretty good. I used some shrimp and some crawfish, i also put in 1teaspoon of cream cheese. I will def. be cooking this one again. We ate it with noodles this time, next time i might change it up a bit and eat over rice. good luck!
We have decreased the amount of garlic powder in this recipe to 1 tablespoon. We believe the 1 cup was a mistakenly typed in by the submitter.

This recipe was no doubt quick and easy; however, it was simply disappointing (where is the orange coloring typical of etoufee recipes) and, if I had not edited the ingredients, would have been completely inedible (i.e., used 1/4 cup of garlic powder instead of the full 1 cup that the recipe indicated). Considering the expense of seafood, I would choose to use mine differently next time.
